DataElement.preferredName: Therapeutic Procedure Progression-Free Monoclonal Anti-GD2 Administered Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria Yes No Not Applicable Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no/not applicable indicator related to a therapeutic procedure involving administration of monoclonal antibody GD2 anti-idiotype vaccine and progression-free survival as a determinant of eligibility for participation in a clinical trial.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Therapeutic Procedure Progression-Free Monoclonal Anti-GD2 Administered Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a therapeutic procedure involving administration of monoclonal antibody GD2 anti-idiotype vaccine and progression-free survival as a determinant of eligibility for participation in a clinical trial.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.

Property.preferredName: Progression-free Survival Monoclonal Antibody GD2 Anti-Idiotype Vaccine Administered Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
Property.preferredDefinition: The length of time during and after treatment in which a patient is living with a disease that does not get worse. Progression-free survival may be used in a clinical study or trial to help find out how well a new treatment works.:A class of vaccines that consist of anti-idiotype monoclonal antibodies against the tumor-associated antigen disialoganglioside GD2 with potential antineoplastic activity.  Vaccination with a monoclonal antibody GD2 anti-idiotype vaccine produces an immunoglobulin response against GD2 with subsequent destruction of GD2 positive tumor cells via antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).  GD2 is overexpressed in melanoma, neuroblastoma, soft tissue sarcoma, and small cell carcinoma of the lung. (NCI04):The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).:Elements of a personal medical history which are necessary to allow an individual to participate in a specific clinical trial.

Concepts.definition: The length of time during and after treatment in which a patient is living with a disease that does not get worse. Progression-free survival may be used in a clinical study or trial to help find out how well a new treatment works.

A class of vaccines that consist of anti-idiotype monoclonal antibodies against the tumor-associated antigen disialoganglioside GD2 with potential antineoplastic activity.  Vaccination with a monoclonal antibody GD2 anti-idiotype vaccine produces an immunoglobulin response against GD2 with subsequent destruction of GD2 positive tumor cells via antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).  GD2 is overexpressed in melanoma, neuroblastoma, soft tissue sarcoma, and small cell carcinoma of the lung. (NCI04)
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).
Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.
